conclusion: Analyze the refraction of light through the hemispherical shell to determine the radius of the circular boundary.
Light rays are incident on the inner surface of the hemispherical shell with radius R, parallel to the axis of symmetry, and refract at the inner and outer surfaces with radius √2R.
At the inner surface, the angle of incidence θ_i is the same as the angle the ray makes with the radial line from the center O to the point of incidence.
Using Snell's law: n_air sin θ_i = n sin θ_r, where n_air = 1 and n is the refractive index of the medium.
For a point on the edge of the incident beam, θ = π/2, so sin θ_i = 1 and sin θ_r = 1/n.
At the outer surface, using Snell's law: n sin θ_r = n_air sin θ_o, leading to sin θ_o = 1 and θ_o = π/2.
The light ray is refracted such that it is tangent to the outer surface of the hemispherical shell.
The radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface is the radius of the outer surface, √2R.
The radius of the circular boundary where light rays are transmitted is √2R.
